author: Steven Bird
title: Added partial support for mapping of tagsets. Currently only works for the Universal Tagset (Petrov, Das, McDonald, 2012). Existing support for a simplified tagset (via simplify_tags=True) is dropped. Access new mappings via tagset='universal', optional flag for corpus reader methods that return pos-tagged text.

author: Peter Ljunglöf
title: Fixed comparisons for Python 3. - replaced `__cmp__` with `__eq__`, `__ne__` and `__lt__`, and `@total_ordering` - added `__hash__` whenever `__eq__` is defined (new py3 semantics for `__hash__`) - replaced `cmp` keyword argument with `key` in calls to `sort`/`sorted` - different types should not in general be orderable, so `__lt__` raises a TypeError in these cases (exception: Tree and FeatStruct)

author: Mark Amery
title: Substantial rewrite of the Porter Stemmer. This was to: 1) Make it threadsafe 2) Make it more Pythonic and remove at least some of the weird C-like code from    when it was originally ported from C 3) Remove nonsense comments referring to things like null terminated strings and    char arrays that are meaningless in a Python context (again the result of it    originally being ported from C) 4) Make it faster.

author: Mikhail Korobov
title: nose raises an exception under python 3 while trying to discover tests from nltk.compat. I was unable to get it excluded with '--exclude' option so the hack-ish workaround is applied: executable bit is added to compat.py (nose skips executable files by default). There should be a better way to do this.

author: Mikhail Korobov
title: Unbound methods are gone in Py3 so there is no easy way to support 'overridden' function for unbound methods in Py3 because they look like regular functions and doesn't store reference to a class. That feature is not used in NLTK own codebase so I removed it from tests. This make 'nltk.internals' tests ("tox -- nltk.internals internals.doctest") pass for all platforms.

author: Dan Garrette
title: Created special exception hierarchy for Prover9 errors.  Fatal errors indicate serious issues such as malformed syntax.  LimitExeeded exceptions indicate that Prover9 has cut itself off because the proof was taking too long.  The distinction is useful because the undecidablity of first-order logic means that it may be useful to simply assume that long-running proofs are non-theorems.

author: Edward Loper
title: Modified nltk-internal imports to import values from the modules where they are defined -- e.g., changed "from nltk import FreqDist" to "from nltk.probability import FreqDist".  This helps to avoid circular import problems, and will be helpful if we choose to do any lazy importing to speed up nltk import time.

author: Steven Bird
title: Docbook xlinks are rendered as "Figure X", "Example X", "Section X", "Table X", "Chapter X" etc.  When the underlying text includes the object type, the resulting output has "Section Section X".  Therefore, all instances of these words before a citation in our source text, e.g. "Section sec-foo_", have now been deleted.

author: Brandon Craig Rhodes
title: Made the NLTK egg able to run its own tests.  Most of them seem to fail without the NLTK data set loaded, but, still.  One test was not able to run on the standard Python doctest runner, so I combined a split line into a single line, which seemed to solve the problem. (Apologies in advance if this ruins the normal test runs.)

author: Steven Bird
title: Fixed bug 209 reported by Jordan Boyd-Graber. The default behavior of the wordlist corpus reader was to look for a file called "en"; however this is specific to the stopwords corpus.  In general we cannot specify a default file.  It is reasonable to allow users not to specify a file (and get all files; the current behavior) in the case of corpora like "names".

author: Steven Bird
title: */chart.py: Fixes in response to http://code.google.com/p/nltk/issues/detail?id=36. draw/chart:PseudoEarleyRule used the TopDownMatchRule() for its scanner; I modified it to use ScannerRule() instead; and modified parse/chart:ScannerRule() to allow an empty lexicon during initialization, and to create it on the fly if necessary.

title: - Allow short-circuiting when checking whether an expression is satisfied.   E.g., for A&B, return false immediately if we find that A is false.   This can make the evaluation of deeply nested epxressions like   (exists x.(P(x) & exists y.(Q(y) & exists z.(R(y) ...)))) much faster.

author: Dan Garrette
title: - Reorganized VariableExpression types   - Abstract parent class is now called AbstractVariableExpression   - Three concrete classes: FunctionVariableExpression (ie, "P"), IndividualVariableExpression (ie, "x"), and ConstantExpression, (ie, "walk")   - A function VariableExpression() exists as a factory that creates the correct subtype of AbstractVariableExpression based on the name of the variable passed in.  This is the preferred way to construct any AbstractVariableExpression object.

author: Steven Bird
title: Changed the way we do program listings.  Docbook doesn't let us define custom floating figure environments, so they have been treated as inline examples.  However, they need to be treated as floats, so they have to be figures.  This means they have to be numbered along with figures, and referred to from the text as Figure N.N instead of Listing N.N. A further consequence is that: "Listing N.N shows" -> "The program in Figure N.N shows", so all the source chapters that contain pylistings have had to be tweaked.

author: Steven Bird
title: Reorganise ch02 to a new structure that opens with linguistically and technically motivated content rather than just language syntax, then progresses through an alternating series of sections on Python and linguistic tasks.  The old material on lemmatization and stemming has been moved from the end to the start, since this connects with the word-counting theme of ch01 and may permit some nice exercises on indexing (e.g. to do more sophisticated concordancing when we only require word stems to match).  Several independent chunks of text on files and strings have been aggregated into a single section, but this still needs to be reworked internally.  Readers encounter regular expressions first in the context of cleaning XML, then see some simple tokenization, before a thorough treatment of regular expressions once they've had this motivation.  A section on string formatting comes last (mapping from lists to strings), complementing the tokenization section (mapping from strings to lists).

author: Edward Loper
title: Merged zipdata branch changes r6304:6324 into the trunk.  This branch adds support for reading corpora and other data files from within zipfiles. - nltk.data.find() can now handle .zip files as part of a resource   name -- e.g., nltk.find('corpora/treebank.zip/combined/wsj_0001.mrg') - nltk.data.find() can now handle .zip files as entries for   nltk.path - nltk.data.find() now returns PathPointers rather than path   strings.  PathPointers can point to either filesystem objects   (with the subclass FileSystemPathPointer) or to files within   zipfiles (using ZipFilePathPointer). - StreamBackedCorpusReader now accepts PathPointer values for its   constructor's filename argument - Modified all corpora to take PathPointer values for 'root'.

PathPointers can point to either filesystem objects   (with the subclass FileSystemPathPointer) or to files within   zipfiles (using ZipFilePathPointer). - StreamBackedCorpusReader now accepts PathPointer values for its   constructor's filename argument - Modified all corpora to take PathPointer values for 'root'.

author: Edward Loper
title: Merged zipdata branch changes r6304:6324 into the trunk.  This branch adds support for reading corpora and other data files from within zipfiles. - nltk.data.find() can now handle .zip files as part of a resource   name -- e.g., nltk.find('corpora/treebank.zip/combined/wsj_0001.mrg') - nltk.data.find() can now handle .zip files as entries for   nltk.path - nltk.data.find() now returns PathPointers rather than path   strings.  PathPointers can point to either filesystem objects   (with the subclass FileSystemPathPointer) or to files within   zipfiles (using ZipFilePathPointer). - StreamBackedCorpusReader now accepts PathPointer values for its   constructor's filename argument - Modified all corpora to take PathPointer values for 'root'.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added support for constructing trees from strings with Tree(s).   This is basically equivalent to Tree.parse(s). - Turned ImmutableTree.node into a read-only property.  This ensures   that any attempt to edit an immutable tree results in an exception. - Added ImmutableParentedTree and ImmutableMultiParentedTree - Fixed bug that caused ProbabilisticTree constructor to fail.

title: - Changed to use urllib2 rather than urllib.  urllib2 responds in a   somewhat more useful way to error conditions.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed bugs in BinaryMaxentFeatureEncoding.encode() for unseen   features. - Changed BinaryMaxentFeatureEncoding.length() to just return   self._length, rather than trying to recompute it (which it was   doing wrong anyway)

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed a bug where BinaryMaxentFeatureEncoding's length was not   adjusted properly when alwayson features were added.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added methods for doing error analysis with maxent models:   MaxentClassifier.explain() and   MaxentClassifier.show_most_informative_features().

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added 'tree_class' param to ConllCorpusReader constructor - Changed definition of ConllCorpusReader._read_grid_block to   deal with empty blocks & EOF better. - Fixed bug in code to find the predicate in a Conll srl instance - Fixed handling of pos_in_tree arguments to parsed_sents() and   srl_instances() (they were being ignored) - Added ConllSRLInstanceList -- used for srl_instances when   flatten=False.  It defines pprint(), which generates the conll   output format.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added filename property to StreamBackedCorpusView - Fixed bug in bounds checking for cached values - Fixed bug caused caused by previous checkin moving slice_bounds   to nltk.internals - Added PickleCorpusView

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed bug in AbstractLazySequence.__cmp__ - Improved efficiency of LazyMap.iterate_from(), esp when   applied to lazy subsequences.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Improvements to the confusion matrix display   - fixed bug in aligning columns when values have different lengths   - optionally sort values by count   - mark the diagonal values   - use '.' for zeros

author: Edward Loper
title: Fixed minor bug in type checking for 'brackets' argument of Tree.parse().

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed bug in regression test (expecting wrong exception)

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed minor bug in type checking for 'brackets' argument of Tree.parse().

author: Edward Loper
title: - Updated test output to reflect a fixed bug (it was printing out   the wrong error level for the best stump).

author: Edward Loper
title: - Minor docstring fixes

title: - Set __docformat__ for nltk.wordnet.browser

author: Edward Loper
title: - Updated docstring for Model.i() to reflect a change made in svn   revision 6180 (parameter 'expr' was renamed to 'parsed')

author: Edward Loper
title: - Updated docstring for Model.i() to reflect a change made in svn   revision 6180 (parameter 'expr' was renamed to 'parsed')

author: Edward Loper
title: - Set __docformat__ in nltk.decorator to restructuredtext.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Removed unused chunk_types from iob_words and iob_sents.

author: Edward Loper
title: - New changelog entries:   - Added ParentedTree & MultiParentedTree.   - Added nps_chat corpus   - Improved support for lazy sequences   - Added support for reading '04 and '05 conll corpora   - Added ProbDistI.generate()

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed typo bug in ElementWrapper

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added ParentedTree and MultiParentedTree

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed bug in trace message for best_stump()

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed exception string for feature structure parse errors when the   parsed string contains newlines.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed a bug in bracketed tree parsing where ((A a) (B b)) would get   parsed as (A a).  This happened because the code to get rid of   redundant empty top bracketings was buggy.

author: Edward Loper
title: Fixed a bug that could cause infinite recursion when comparing a tree to a non-tree

author: Edward Loper
title: - fixed bug where trees would sometimes fail when sliced - changed tree repr to print the class of the tree (eg ImmutableTree)   instead of just Tree - changed immutable trees to precompute their hash value.  This saves some   time, and ensures that we fail early if the user tries to make an   immutable tree with mutable node value or children

author: Edward Loper
title: moved nltk.utilities.AbstractLazySequence._slice_bounds to nltk.internals.slice_bounds, since it's really a general-purpose function, and is useful for other clases.

author: Edward Loper
title: moved nltk.utilities.AbstractLazySequence._slice_bounds to nltk.internals.slice_bounds, since it's really a general-purpose function, and is useful for other clases.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed bug in ConllCorpusReader.parsed_sents where '(' or ')' is   used as a word or a pos tag -- they get mapped to '-LRB-' and   '-RRB-' now. - ConllCorpusReader.srl_spans now returns ((start, end), argid)   tuples rather than (argid, start, end) tuples. - Added ConllCorpusReader.srl_instances, which returns   ConllSRLInstance objects.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added Tree.leave_treeposition() and Tree.treeposition_spanning_leaves(),   both of which convert leaf indices to tree positions.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added ProbDistI.generate() method.  The default implementation just   walks through the sample list until the cumulative probability of   the samples it's looked at exceeds a random number between 0 and 1.   Subclasses are free to define more efficient implementations where   possible (but this hasn't been done yet). - Added SUM_TO_ONE class variable to ProbDistI, to indicate whether a   probability distribution's probability estimates for its samples   should always sum to one.  (Some don't because they 'discard' some   probability mass to be used for unspecified unseen samples.) - Added missing samples() method to a couple prob dist classes - Added generation test to the demo code

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed a bug in LazySubsequence.iterate_from(start) which caused it to   yield too many elements when start>0. - In LazyConcatenation, iterate through the list-of-lists rather than   checking its length and indexing.  This is useful, e.g., if the   underlying list-of-lists comes from a corpus view, in which case   calculating the length of the list-of-lists would require scanning   the entire corpus.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added PropbankPointer as a base class for the three propbank pointer   classes. - Fixed a bug in the PropbankTreePointer __cmp__ implementation when   compared with objects that are not PropbankTreePointers. - Changed the block size for the propbank corpus reader from 20 lines   to 100 lines.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added new ConllCorpusReader, which provides a superset of the   functionality provided by ConllChunkCorpusReader.  E.g., it can   read parse trees and semantic role labelings in the formats used   in CoNLL 2004 and 2005.  ConllChunkCorpusReader is now a subclass   of ConllCorpusReader.

author: Dan Garrette
title: logic.py  - Fixed parser so that "-a -> b" is parsed as "(-a) -> b" instead of "-(a -> b)"  - Improved the way different syntaxes are chosen.  "str(ex)" calls the default syntax, while "ex.str(syntax)" can be used to choose a different syntax.  ie, "ex.str(logic.Tokens.PROVER9)" yields Prover9 syntax.

"str(ex)" calls the default syntax, while "ex.str(syntax)" can be used to choose a different syntax.  ie, "ex.str(logic.Tokens.PROVER9)" yields Prover9 syntax.

author: Dan Garrette
title: logic.py  - Removed global function unique_variable() in favor of a method on Expression  - Added is_indvar() global function to verify that a string is the appropriate form for an individual variable  - Modified the parser so that higher-order expressions are not allowed.  This is accomplished by requiring that variables bound by quantifiers be individual variables and preventing predicates from being individual variables.  So now, 'exists P.P(x)' and 'y(x)' will both throw errors.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added 'jar' target to top-level Makefile and to the javasrc/   Makefile, which builds 'nltk.jar' and places it in the   nltk/nltk/ directory.  Building this target requires that   Mallet be installed; if it is not installed, then a message   is displayed indicating how to download it, and how to tell   the Makefile where it is located. - Added 'nltk.jar' to the repository.  This file can also be   built from the Makefile, but doing so requires the correct   dependencies; so I'm also including it in the repository. - Added nltk.internals.NLTK_JAR, which is the full path to the   nltk.jar file.  (Note that this file may not exist.) - In nltk.internals.java(), accept the string 'pipe' and treat   it as subprocess.PIPE (this is just for convenience) - Modified setup.py and MANIFEST.in to include nltk.jar file.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added 'jar' target to top-level Makefile and to the javasrc/   Makefile, which builds 'nltk.jar' and places it in the   nltk/nltk/ directory.  Building this target requires that   Mallet be installed; if it is not installed, then a message   is displayed indicating how to download it, and how to tell   the Makefile where it is located. - Added 'nltk.jar' to the repository.  This file can also be   built from the Makefile, but doing so requires the correct   dependencies; so I'm also including it in the repository. - Added nltk.internals.NLTK_JAR, which is the full path to the   nltk.jar file.  (Note that this file may not exist.) - In nltk.internals.java(), accept the string 'pipe' and treat   it as subprocess.PIPE (this is just for convenience) - Modified setup.py and MANIFEST.in to include nltk.jar file.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added CustomFeatureValue, which can be used to define classes for   base feature values that define custom unification methods.  (This   hook is necessary for some of Petro's work on porting FUF to nltk;   and it might be useful in other cases too.)  Note that this new hook   allows an alternative approach to the existing hook supplied by the   Feature class: the Feature class allows you to define 'magic   features,' while the CustomFeatureValue class allows you to define   'magic feature values.' - Defer binding variables until the end of unification.  This is   necessary when variables are used together with CustomFeatureValue   (or with custom Feature objects).

author: Steven Bird
title: Modified wordnet similarity code to use pre-built information content files available from the WordNet Similarity website [http://wn-similarity.sourceforge.net] and included with the NLTK Corpus distribution. author: Edward Loper
title: - Refactored the code that makes calls to prover9 and mace4.  The old   file was leaving lots of old files in /tmp; and was using some fixed   file names (in /tmp) that would cause conflicts between users on   a given system.  The new code avoids temp files altogether by using   pipes for input and output.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Refactored the code that makes calls to prover9 and mace4.  The old   file was leaving lots of old files in /tmp; and was using some fixed   file names (in /tmp) that would cause conflicts between users on   a given system. author: Edward Loper
title: - Improvements to nltk's maxent classifier & weka classifier   - refactored feature encoding to allow for features that depend     on the output in a nontrivial way   - added support for using MEGAM to train maxent classifiers   - added support for using scipy maxent trainers, if scipy is     installed (CG, etc.)   - added apply_features util function (and LazyMappedList class), which     makes it easy to train classifiers on large data sets without     using huge amounts of memory -- in particular, we don't need to     store the full list of featureset objects in memory at once.

author: Ewan Klein
title: * Expanded note about using Python 'help()' in Sect 2.1 * Expanded Sect 2.2. * Polished some of the text about Shoebox (Sect 2.5) * Added a sentence at the end of intro to Sect 3. * Added a bit about CS students not being linguistically very literate   in first para of Section 3.1 * Expanded 3.4 (first assignment) * Some polishing of 2nd para in Sect 5.

author: Steven Bird
title: * moved some of intro discussion on expectations to a new subsection on articulating   the goals of the course, in section 3 * removed section 2.2 on diversity of programming experience to section 5, since the   previous section 2.1 on Python also covered this, and since 2.2 was mostly about   assignments which fits best in section 5 * changed "completely self-contained" to just "self-contained" * fixed example re WhitespaceTokenizer which seemed to be expecting the constructor   to do the tokenizing. * added sentence to section 3 opening to serve as overview of section * suggested another area of content for the first lecture (shared history of CS and ling) * started work on a figure to provide code examples that would illustrate Jason's point   about exercises that do/n't use NLTK functionality * terminology: changed "problem" to "exercise" in a few places

author: Steven Bird
title: * rewrote introduction to try to highlight the issues with the students native language   (linguistics vs computer science) * wrote opening to section on getting started, to explain the importance of this   given the diverse student audience, and students voting with their feet * added discussion of student expectations * notes on first assignment, aiming to show how one assignment could address   the distinct learning needs of the two different audiences * added citation of ACM paper that talks about Python's suitability for an audience   with widely varying programming skills

author: Steven Bird
title: * moved sentence about NLTK's uniqueness to earlier paragraph where it fitted better * deleted sentence about the fact that providing code amounted to a bias in favour   of CS students, since: (i) the more CS-biased texts don't provide any code, just   exercises that presume people can code, and (ii) NLTK does a lot of convenient   housekeeping in its code (e.g. the corpus readers) which is of primary benefit to   the linguist audience * moved 2.5 after 2.1 since both relate to the need to have an accessible   programming language * changed title of Shoebox section to mention files (we're not interfacing to   the Shoebox software directly, only via a common file format) * moved 4.3 into section 5, as a more natural place to talk about assignments   (sec 4 is on classroom interaction, while 5 was on projects but now expanded   to be on assignments and projects) * changed texttt inline code to use a \code macro that makes it smaller

author: Edward Loper
title: Minor redesign of the corpus readers.  Instead of using 'items' or 'documents' to refer to files, just use "file identifiers," i.e., relative paths from the root of the corpus.  This increases transparency and avoids making any commitment about whether something's a document or not.  When appropriate, corpora can also chose to define and use other identifiers.  E.g., timit defines "utterance identifiers" and treebank defines "document identifiers."

author: Edward Loper
title: - LineTokenizer now takes a parameter, blanklines, which specifies how   blank lines should be handled. (can be 'discard', 'keep', or   'discard-eof'.)  Default value is 'discard'. - Added line_tokenize function.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added missing import

author: Edward Loper
title: - When a corpus view slice is created that's more than 100 words long,   return a CorpusViewSlice object rather than a list.  That way, if   you e.g. split a corpus into a train set and a test set, you don't   need to load the whole corpus into memory.  (The number 100 is   controlled by the const CorpusViewSlice.MIN_SIZE. - Corpus views now act a little more like (immutable) lists -- they   implement count(), index(), __contains__, __add__, __mul__, and   __cmp__.  This was mainly done for the benefit of CorpusViewSlice,   so that if the user takes a large-ish slice they'll still be able   to use normal 'list' methods on it. - Corpus views are now explicitly un-hashable. - Fixed a bug in the handling of slice indexes that are more negative   than the size of the corpus (e.g., for a corpus with 100 words, an   index of -170 would previously get treated as if it were 30; but it   should get treated as if it's 0.) - Added read_line_block - Added some regression test cases for corpus views.

author: Edward Loper
title: Updated the nltk.tokenize package.   - All tokenizers are now available as subclasses of TokenizeI   - Selected tokenizers are also available as functions   - Function names are "whitespace_tokenize()", "wordpunct_tokenize()",     etc.  The old "tokenize.whitespace()" etc names are still available,     but should be considered deprecated!  They will be removed before     nltk 1.0.   - Simplified the code in regexp tokenizer.  It now delegates to     utilities.convert_regexp_to_nongrouping to convert grouping parens     to nongrouping ones.  Once this is done, it can simply use     re.findall() (for gaps=False) and re.split() (for gaps=True).     I also added a flag to control whether empty tokens are discarded     when gaps=True -- defaults to True (matching the original behavior).   - Changed implementation of sexpr tokenizer to something more efficient.     Tested on treebank text, it runs about twice as fast.  I also added     options for specifying custom parenthases (e.g., for [..[..]] style     trees) a 'strict' parameter to decide whether mismatched parens gives     an exception, or returns a list containing partial sexprs.

They will be removed before     nltk 1.0.   - Simplified the code in regexp tokenizer. author: Edward Loper
title: added ycoe corpus reader -- removed some old ycoe code, including the code for chunking.  This code might be moved to contrib at some point. author: Edward Loper
title: Transformed corpus modules to corpus readers.  Individual corpora will now be read by instances of these CorpusReader classes.  E.g., all of the plaintext corpora (abc, udhr, inaugural, etc) become instances of PlaintextCorpusReader, rather than separate modules.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Fixed bug in concat() -- accept subtypes of known types as well - Changed read_whitespace_block and read_wordpunct_block to read   blocks of 20 lines at a time (rather than 1 line at a time).   This will cut down on space overhead by a factor of about 20x,   and might actually increase local random-access performance,   because of the cache.  Random access that's really random (e.g.,   selecting words from the document in random order), will become   a little slower.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Modified all corpus readers to accept lists of items; in which case,   they return 'concatenations' of the given corpus items.  If the   underlying corpus items are strings or lists, the obvious operation   is performed.  If they're StreamBackedCorpusViews, then a new   ConcatenatedCorpusView object is used.  If they're xml, then a new   xml element is created, containing all of them, with tag 'documents'. - Got rid of _block_reader -- it was redundant w/ read_block - StreamBackedCorpusView now requires a filename (not a stream). - StreamBackedCorpusView now doesn't open the file until it needs to. - StreamBackedCorpusView now doesn't calculate eofpos until it needs to. - StreamBackedCorpusView can now be closed and re-opened.  If it is   closed, it will be automatically re-opened next time it is accessed. - StreamBackedCorpusView's iterate_from method is now public - Fixed bug w/ negative indices (indexerror wasn't getting thrown   in some cases where it should get thrown) - Fixed bug w/ length calculation (last block was getting omitted from   the length calculation) - Changed KeyError -> IndexError for out-of-bounds indexing in   StreamBackedCorpusView - Added ConcatenatedCorpusView - Added some default values for corpus read methods - Fixed typo in brown corpus demo

If they're xml, then a new   xml element is created, containing all of them, with tag 'documents'. - Got rid of _block_reader -- it was redundant w/ read_block - StreamBackedCorpusView now requires a filename (not a stream). - StreamBackedCorpusView now doesn't open the file until it needs to. - StreamBackedCorpusView now doesn't calculate eofpos until it needs to. - StreamBackedCorpusView can now be closed and re-opened.  If it is   closed, it will be automatically re-opened next time it is accessed. - StreamBackedCorpusView's iterate_from method is now public - Fixed bug w/ negative indices (indexerror wasn't getting thrown   in some cases where it should get thrown) - Fixed bug w/ length calculation (last block was getting omitted from   the length calculation) - Changed KeyError -> IndexError for out-of-bounds indexing in   StreamBackedCorpusView - Added ConcatenatedCorpusView - Added some default values for corpus read methods - Fixed typo in brown corpus demo

author: Steven Bird
title: nltk_lite/parse/*.py * added cfg.covers() to check that a grammar covers a sentence   (i.e. all the words in the sentence appear in lexical productions) * added AbstractParse._check_coverage() which raises a ValueError   if the grammar doesn't cover the sentence * modified get_parse and get_parse_list in the various parser classes   to perform this check (nowhere to abstract this). * modified pchart demo code because parser didn't cover grammar

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added book.txt, used to generate the entire book as a single html   or pdf file.  A single pagination is used across the entire book,   and crossreferences between chapters works fine.  A table of contents   and an index are generated. - Added support for external (cross-chapter) cross-referencing - Added support for defined terms (`foo`:dt:) and indexed terms   (`foo`:idx:) - Added index.txt, used to generate `index.html`, an index that points   to the separate `<chapter>.html` files for each defined term or   indexed term. - Tweaked heading contents for latex output - Section numbering is now handled by a custom transform, which will   appropriately handle appendices, prefaces, and setting latex   chapter counters where appropriate. - Fixed some section headings in `semantics.txt` - Added missing import in tree2image.py

author: David Ormiston Smith
title: - Added lexname object creation (previously found in the Wordnet distro after patching). Although this reduces the number of steps end-users have to take to get the nltk_lite.wordnet module up and running, the lexname data is maintained by the creators of Wordnet proper and they may update it at any time. - Some comments updated.

author: David Ormiston Smith
title: - Now fully functional (some cleaning and tweaking still required). Outputs a file with two pickled dicts containing the frequency counts for synsets of all words sourced from the Brown corpus. - This module will probably need to be redesigned at some point to adhere to a standard interface for data generation. But it does at least work :)

author: David Ormiston Smith
title: - Contains methods that create a frequency distribution for nouns and verbs encountered in the Brown corpus. It is designed so that it should be run once after the nltk_lite.wordnet package is installed (and subsequently whenever Wordnet proper is updated) and it will generate a data file containing the word frequencies. The file output functionality still needs to be added at this time. The method structure will also probably be revised in the future.

author: David Ormiston Smith
title: - Added new methods path_distance_similarity(), leacock_chodorow_similarity() and wu_palmer_similarity() to the Sense class. All three return a number denoting the similarity of two Senses. The first two are more or less complete and give the same results as do Pedersen's Perl versions (http://www.d.umn.edu/~tpederse/similarity.html) but the third does not, because of an ambiguity in the algorithm. - Also added one support class (OrderedSynset) and a couple of utility methods; these may be moved to the wntools.py file later.

author: David Ormiston Smith
title: - Fixed selection sort such that the supplied list is correctly sorted.  - Merge sort does NOT function as intended. I believe this is due to scoping issues - the assignment of the newly merged list is lost once each recursive call returns. This cannot be easily solved without returning the list (as opposed to reordering it in-place, as the other sort methods do).

title: Fixed a couple of bugs: * 'check_reentrances' should be 'check_reentrance' * It seems the FeatureBindings constructor could never be run with arguments,   because it expected them as keyword arguments (with **initial_bindings), but   the keys of 'initial_bindings' are FeatureVariables, and the keys of keyword   arguments have to be strings. I changed 'bindings' to a plain argument to   make this work.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Check that the children argument is not a string (this is to prevent   people from accidentally saying things like Tree('x', 'y') instead   of Tree('x', ['y']). - Check that the first element of a tree-position index to an int.   Otherwise, if the user says tree['foo'], they'll get an infinite   recursion (because 'f'[0] = 'f').  This way, they'll get something   like "'f' is not an int".

author: Edward Loper
title: - Christopher Maloof's implementation of the Brill tagger, with lots of   clean-up.  This is copied from contrib/nltk_contrib/upenn/cis530/   spring2003/christopher_maloof, with the following changes:     - training split out into different classes (BrillTaggerTrainer,       FastBrillTaggerTrainer)     - merged rules.py into brill.py     - renamed the brill rule & template classes.  (eg RuleI -> BrillRuleI)     - Completed changes to use new token architecture (w/ property       indirection, etc)     - Several nomenclature changes, to make things more clear (e.g.,       introduced the term "fixscore" to distinguish from the actual       score, etc.)     - Refactored & simplified templates & rules     - Improved trace output     - Removed explicit save/load functions (you can just pickle the       tagger itself).     - refactored _best_rule, to make it shorter & easier to read (added       several helper methods)     - lots of code & docstring clean-up

author: Edward Loper
title: - Moved docstrings from ctoken.c to ctoken.h - Changed location context implementation to use Python tuples instead   of structs.  (This allows for better garbage collection, etc).  But   the location-context tuples should never be visible from python. - Changed type implementation: now each type contains a pointer to   a property name list; and only the property values are stored inside   the type object.  This means that types can share property name   lists (facilitated by a cache), so the avg size overhead for types   decreases by about 1 word per type. - Always maintain the property name lists in sorted order (sorted by   the ids of property names, which are interned strings).  This makes   comparisons between properties easier. - fixed a few minor bugs - Added more documentation

author: Edward Loper
title: - Improvements to the efficiency of the type object:   - Use the VAR protocol to store a type's properties directly in     the type object (rather than in a separate auxilliary array).     This saves 1 word/type (down from 4+2p to 3+2p, where p is the     number of properties defined by the type).

author: Edward Loper
title: - Improvements to the efficiency of the location object:   - Define a LocationContext object, that's used to store a     <unit,source> pair.  These are shared among locations, so each     location only needs one pointer for unit/source, not 2 (saves     ~1 word/location); and makes several operations faster (since     we can check for pointer equality between LocationContext     objects before doing a full equality check).   - Intern unit strings.   - added a new implementation, nltkLen1Location, which is used for     locations with a length of 1.  These objects don't store an     end index; only a start index.  (saves 1 word/location for the     common case of length-1 locations).   These improvements take the average space/location down from 6   words/location (=24 bytes) to 4 words/location (=16 bytes).  c.f.   to ~35-40 words (140-160 bytes) that are used by the Python   implementation.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Replaced dictionary-based implementation of Type with an array-based   implementation.  The new implementation also interns property names,   for efficiency. - Added a preliminary (and very experimental) Token implementation. - Fixed a couple memory problems.

title: - Changed sort order for chart edges - Added a sort to TopDownRule, to give it the same behavior as   Earley's algorithm (this may be removed when we actually add   Earley's algorithm). - Sort the edges for BottomUpRule, so we process them left-to-right - Sort the incomplete edges for FR, to give it the same behavior as   Earley's algorithm (this may be removed when we actually add   Earley's algorithm). - Changed order of rules in TD_STRATEGY - Changed SteppingChartParser.step to continue using a rule for   as long as it applies (to give Earley's algorithm behavior).   This may get removed later. - Reverse the order of the new chart edges in SteppingChartParser,   so they match the order used in the normal ChartParser.

author: Edward Loper
title: Complete rewrite of nltk.probability.  The new nltk.probability is less flexible in some ways, but should work out better.  It is signifigantly simpler, which should make it easier for students to understand.  Also, under the old design, doing statistical estimation would be very cumbersome.   - no more events   - FreqDist is now a class, not an interface   - FreqDist.cond_max and FreqDist.cond_freq are replaced by using a new     class, ConditionalFreqDist, to encode conditional frequency     distributions.   - Similarly, ConditionalProbDist replaces ProbDistI.cond_max and     ProbDistI.cond_prob.   - Rewrote the probability distributions   - Added docs to probability distributions   - Freq dists no longer have bins; the number of bins is specified     when doing statistical estimation, if necessary   - CrossValidationProbDist now uses HeldoutProbDist to do most of its     work.

author: Edward Loper
title: Overhaul of the chart parser, to simplify it and make it consistant with the new parser interface..   - Defined an interface for chart rules   - Replaced ChartParserStrategy class with just lists of chart rules   - Updated to work with new parser interfaces   - Updated to work with new CFG definition   - Made 2 implementations of the chart parser: 1 uses what were formerly     called "static rules" and the other uses what were formerly called     "edge triggered rules".  The static one is the simpler -- its rules     are ChartRules and it is ChartParser.  The one with what were "edge     triggered rules" is IncrementalChartParser, and it uses     IncrementalChartRules.  The intuition is that each rule is defined     in terms of which new edges to add, *given that a specific edge was     just added*.  Note that this is *not* necessary for any rules, but     does help efficiency a lot for some (e.g., fundamental, bottom-up,     etc)   - Got rid of a bunch of docstrings (they're not correct/relevant anymore)   - Got rid of callbacks   - Removed a bunch of accessors (they may get added back soon)   - Completely new definition of SteppingChartParser (it's a bit cleaner     now) based on ChartParser (not IncrementalChartParser)   - New demo code   - Don't rely on edge.fr, edge.self_loop_end, etc, since we're phasing     those out.

title: - Overhall of docstrings - General clean-up - Changed parsers to use PCFGs (instead of lists of rules) - Added trace output to parsers - Major overhaul of Insideparser (which was renamed to   BottomUpPCFGChartParser, and made an abstract class; InsideParser is   now a simple subclass).     - Add *all* edges (token edges, BU init edges, and FR edges) from       the queue.     - Pass the chart to sort_queue (it might want it)     - Got rid of explicit bottom_up_init     - Renamed add_lexical_edges to init_edge_queue, and changed it to       return the list of edges (not add them to the chart)     - Moved some processing out of _add_edge to parse_n.     - Added _self_loop_n to simplify BU init application     - Simplified _fr - Added subclasses for BottomUpPCFGParser: InsidePCFGParser and   RandomPCFGParser - Misc changes to the test code (including adding a fake lexicalized   grammar).

title: - Added CanvasWidgetI, a base class for canvas widgets.  Canvas widgets   are collections of graphical elements and bindings used to display a   complex object in a Tkinter Canvas. - Added helper functions merge_bbox and adjust_scrollregion.

title: - Changed CanvasNode, CanvasEdge to inherit from CanvasWidgetI   - Renamed draw()/erase() to show()/hide()   - Replaced x()/y() with location()   - Added bbox   - Cleaned up code   - Simplified callbacks   - Implemented attributes (getitem/setitem/constructor, etc) - Added many docstrings - Split add_fs into create_nodes, create_collapsed_edges and   create_expanded_edges - Added support for None elts in CanvasFSA levels - Improved CanvasFSA layout code - Changed constructor argument order for CanvasFoo classes

author: Edward Loper
title: - Moved several values to constants (e.g., NODE_RADIUS) - Added support for selecting between dfs and bfs - Better bounds checking for node-dragging - FSAFrame trys dfs first; if it's too wide, it tries bfs. - test routines updated to be compatible with changes to nltk.fsa - Added support for centered node labels (in addition to above-node   labels); default is currently centered.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Split ChartDemo.apply_strategy into pieces. - Fixed non-stepping application so it places edges on the chart more reasonably.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added classes FSAFrame, which creates a frame with a canvas &   scrollbars, and puts a CanvasFSA in it. - Added class FSAWindow, which gives an easy way to create a window   with an FSAFrame in it. - Added constants VIEWBORDER and SCROLLBORDER to control how much   space is put around the fsa on the canvas - Fixed node-dragging with scrollbars; added bounds checking to   node-dragging - Added _curve attribute to edges, to prevent edge overlap. - Lower edge tags, so the tag_binds of nodes take precedence (makes   node-dragging much easier) - Added code to CanvasEdge to handle self-looping edges - Added a collapse_edge param to CanvasFSA: this causes it to display   mutliple edges between the same nodes as one edge, with their labels   separated by commas. - Improved node-arranging code somewhat: now placing nodes into levels   using depth-first, rather than breadth-first, algorithm. - Added code to properly handle arrangement for cycles: we select the   node which can reach the most unexpanded nodes as the node to add to   level 0. - Got rid of _LevelNode

author: Steven Bird
title: Debugged determinization code Added accessible() to determine node accessibility Added prune() to delete transitions from/to inaccessible states

author: Edward Loper
title: - Changed _Node and _Edge to split draw from construction; now you can construct them,   and wait to draw them (e.g., until you decide where you want them) - Added color() to _Node and _Edge; and font() to _Edge (currently used for epsilon   transitions) - Added erase() methods to hide nodes/edges - Changed _Edge to go from node->node rather than between specific coordinates - Added a preliminary _LevelNode class as a helper for arranging nodes in a level-based   layout - Added preliminary level-based layout algorithm - Changed dimensions of the demo canvas

author: Edward Loper
title: Reimplementing ChunkScore to be more efficient..   - calculate true positive, false positive, false negative counts     as you score.   - removes repeated set union (which was inefficient, esp. since     set union returns a new set)   - keep lists of true positives, false positives, and false     negatives, but limit their size (default=100, but you can     change the limit with keyword args to the constructor)   - interface is (almost completely) compatible with previous impl.

author: Edward Loper
title: - Moved unchunk to chunkparser.py   - Moved chunk scoring code to chunkparser.py.  Converted scoring     code to the ChunkScore class.  ChunkScore is a utility class for     scoring parsers; it can be used to combine scores from multiple     parses (e.g., multiple sentences).  It can also be queried for the     set of missed chunks, incorrect chunks, etc.   - Added ref docs

author: Edward Loper
title: nltk.draw.chart.ChartView:   - general clean-up   - added docstrings   - made FONTSIZE a member variable of the chart, which can be changed     with set_font_size   - Added comments describing all member variables of ChartView   - Fixed bug in RuleView destroy method   - Changed the order of the arguments to ChartView, to make root     optional.  If no root is specified, then a new window is created,     with a "Done" button.   - Made the tree-view frame and the source-view frame optional.  They     are controlled by the keyword arguments "draw_tree" and     "draw_source" to ChartView.  Currently, draw_tree defaults to 0     and draw_source defaults to 1.  The ChartDemo class uses     draw_tree=1 and draw_source=1   - Added facility for marking edges.  Edges can be marked with any     color, using the mark_edge method.  They can be unmarked with     unmark().  This is currently used by ChartDemo to mark the most     recently added edge when stepping.   - Cleaned up & concolidated edge-coloring code.  Now it's all     handled by _color_edge.   - Edges that span the entire chart are now colored green.  This     makes it easier to pick them out.   - Cleaned up edge-selection code   - Changed CHART_LEVEL_SIZE to a member variable; now it varies with     the font size.   - Changed the loclines to be lighter (less visible)

author: Edward Loper
title: - Added a keyword arg to SteppingChartParser.step() "getrule" that   causes it to return a pair of (edge, rule) instead of just an edge.   This is used by draw.ChartDemo to display which rule an edge was   generated by.  We might consider instead adding a new field to edge   that's a string description of the edge, or the rule that generated   it, or something like that.

author: Edward Loper
title: Did a fairly substantial reorganization of the ChartParser module     - Added inline documentation for most methods/classes     - Added a new StrategyClass, and made the notions of chart rule &       strategy more formal.     - Turned rule methods (TD_init) into functions, since this makes it       clearer how you should define new ones.  Also, the old ones used internal       parser variables, etc., which they probably shouldn't.     - Redefined rule functions (TD_init, etc., to return a list of       edges, rather than adding the edges themselves.  The ChartParser       is now responsible for adding them     - Defined some standard strategies     - Wrote a new implementation for SteppingChartParser.  Most likely       broke the old implementation.  The new impl doesn't keep making       new charts (that made nltk.draw.chart very difficult).  The       internal impl of the new SteppingChartParser is a bit messier,       but I think that the interface is cleaner.  (See its usage in       nltk.draw.chart).
